diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels. This condition can lead to various symptoms such as mouth sores, genital sores, skin rashes, and more. The involvement of various system makes it a consideration for these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cogan's syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by inflammation of the eyes and ears, which can lead to vision and hearing problems, respectively. It may also involve systemic manifestations such as lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist. It may cause systemic symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys. It might cause symptoms that align with the ones described, including hearing loss due to its systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can affect any organ and lead to a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations like ulcers and systemic symptoms such as lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on the stage of infection, including neurological problems and arthritis. Early signs can include systemic symptoms like lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels which can cause telangiectasias and lead to symptoms like nosebleeds, and may be associated with systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and damage to the affected organs, which can present a range of symptoms including some matching the ones described.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss syndrome
diagnoses.description: Now also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition causes inflammation of the blood vessels and can involve multiple organs including the nerves (potentially leading to restless leg syndrome), skin, and more.

An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, mainly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the formation of lumps known as granulomas, it can present with lymphadenopathy and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
diagnoses.explanation: CIDP can manifest with increased immunoglobulins, and while less common, can indirectly cause symptoms like pseudoseizures due to neurological involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.explanation: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can lead to a variety of symptoms including angioedema and increased immunoglobulins. Vulvodynia and pseudoseizures may also occur as secondary complications.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.explanation: Certain immunodeficiencies can lead to increased levels of certain immunoglobulins as a compensatory mechanism. Angioedema can also be a symptom in conditions such as hereditary angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.explanation: This condition can lead to hypoferritinemia due to chronic inflammation and increased usage of iron stores. The association with angioedema is less direct but can occur in complex autoimmune syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.explanation: Sjögren's syndrome can cause increased immunoglobulins and has been associated with neurological manifestations that may mimic pseudoseizures. Vulvodynia may occur due to the overall dryness symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.explanation: While primarily known for its neurological symptoms, MS can lead to a variety of systemic effects including increased immunoglobulin levels. Pseudoseizures can sometimes be a manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.explanation: This genetic disorder directly causes angioedema. The relationship with other symptoms such as increased immunoglobulins stems from the complex interplay between the immune system and hereditary factors.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.explanation: This disease can present with a wide array of symptoms, including high levels of immunoglobulins, angioedema, and neurological symptoms that could manifest as pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.explanation: This vasculitis can cause hypoferritinemia due to chronic inflammation. Angioedema and pseudoseizures are less common but possible due to the systemic nature of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.explanation: Typically characterized by low ferritin levels, but its indirect association with the systemic symptoms listed is more complex, possibly through secondary mechanisms related to overall health degradation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could explain the ulcers (due to lack of saliva). Hyperthyroidism has been associated with Sjögren's as well.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can lead to ulcers and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often in reaction to a medication or infection.

diagnoses.name: Reiter's Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can develop in response to an infection in another part of the body, could present with ulcers and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Dry eyes and skin lesions like leukoplakia might be observed.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that leads to blistering and sores (ulcers) on the skin and mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It can also lead to eye problems like dry eyes or more severe eye diseases.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin and mucous membranes, possibly leading to leukoplakia-like lesions and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: While primarily affecting blood's ability to carry oxygen, severe cases can lead to ulcers in the mouth and complications that indirectly could affect eye health. Hyperthyroidism may lead to increased iron turnover.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can cause mouth ulcers and has been associated with neurological changes that could, in theory, affect the nervous control of lacrimal (tear) and salivary glands.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause electrolyte imbalances leading to hypoglycemia, hypertension, and a decrease in appetite. Depression is also common due to the chronic nature of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can lead to thrombosis (thromboembolic disease), thrombocytopenia, and indirectly to other symptoms due to its systemic impact.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause thrombocytopenia, depression, and is associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Poorly managed diabetes can cause hypoglycemia and is a risk factor for thromboembolic disease. Diabetes patients also have higher rates of depression.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause depression, decreased appetite, and can indirectly affect blood pressure control and influence thromboembolic risk.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Leads to increased cortisol levels, causing hypertension, decreased appetite, and has associations with depression. Thromboembolic risk is also elevated.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to thrombocytopenia, hypoglycemia due to poor glycogen storage, and increased risk of thromboembolic disease. Depression can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Cancer (various types)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers can lead to thrombocytopenia, depression, thromboembolic disease, decreased appetite, and hypoglycemia, either directly or due to the treatment.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like rheumatoid arthritis can contribute to depression, decreased appetite, thrombocytopenia, and increased risk of thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to thrombocytopenia, decreased appetite, and indirectly to depression. Patients with HIV/AIDS have an elevated risk of thromboembolic disease and cardiovascular complications including hypertension.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism
Secondary Immunodeficiency due to chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, malignancy)
Chronic infections (e.g., HIV, which could present with hyperthyroidism in rare scenarios)
Hepatitis (A, B, C, E, autoimmune etc.)
Thyroid disease (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Graves' disease)
Secondary Sjögren's syndrome (associated with another autoimmune disease)

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially causing dysautonomias, skin ulcers, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections can lead to pneumonia and Otitis Externa, and contribute to ulcer formation.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can cause dysautonomias, increase the risk of ulcers, and complicate infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Connective Tissue Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as Lupus and Scleroderma can cause dysautonomia, angioedema, and increase the risk of ulcers and infections.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of blood vessels which can lead to dysautonomias, skin ulcers, and contribute to the development of angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that weaken the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infections like pneumonia and Otitis Externa, and complicating angioedema and ulcer healing.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Severe allergies can cause angioedema. Allergic reactions to medications or environmental factors can exacerbate or trigger other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), which could be linked with dysautonomia in complex cases.

diagnoses.name: Skin Conditions
diagnoses.description: Dermatological disorders like Eczema or Psoriasis can lead to skin ulcers and can be associated with Otitis Externa.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Venous Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Poor circulation in the legs can lead to ulcers and may be indirectly associated with dysautonomic symptoms.

diagnoses: Chronic Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stress-Induced Cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo)
diagnoses.detail: Also known as Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy, it often presents after emotional or physical stress and may present with symptoms similar to a heart attack.

diagnoses.name: Acute Sinusitis
diagnoses.detail: Inflammation of the sinuses, often causing facial pain, headache, and nasal congestion, which might be associated with irritability due to discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Pneumonia
diagnoses.detail: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid. Symptoms include cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.detail: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. Basophilia is often observed in blood tests for patients with this condition.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.detail: Overactive thyroid gland that can increase metabolism and lead to irritability, nervousness, and other health issues.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.detail: A group of mental disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear, potentially contributing to irritability.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.detail: An autoimmune disease that can affect many systems including the heart and lungs, potentially leading to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or pneumonia as complications.

diagnoses.name: Mood Disorders
diagnoses.detail: A range of mental health conditions affecting mood, including major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder that might present with irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.detail: A group of conditions characterized by high numbers of eosinophils in the body, which may also present with basophilia.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.detail: Chronic inflammation of the airways that often presents with wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing, which can be exacerbated by respiratory infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder that causes muscle weakness and numbness, primarily in the arms and legs. It may go along with muscle pain and affects the nervous system in a way that could contribute to pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus Infection
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that causes warts on various parts of the body, including the genitals, hands, and feet. It doesn't directly cause the other symptoms, but its presence indicates a compromised immune system, which could be linked to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the quality, timing, and amount of sleep. Frequent waking is a common symptom, which can indirectly affect the body's overall health, potentially contributing to symptoms like muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that lead to an overproduction of blood cells. Thrombocytosis, or an increased number of platelets, is a hallmark of these disorders, which can also cause systemic symptoms like fatigue and bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points. It can be associated with sleep disturbances and can indirectly relate to pseudoseizures due to the stress and discomfort it causes.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizures that occur without a neurological basis, often referred to as pseudoseizures. They can be triggered by psychological stress but can occur alongside various physical health issues.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare chronic blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of platelets by the bone marrow, leading to thrombocytosis. It can also cause complications that indirectly lead to symptoms like fatigue and muscle aches.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets. While the primary issue is bleeding, it can be associated with other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including joint pain, skin rashes, and kidney problems. It can potentially explain a combination of muscle pain, sleep disturbances, and hematological abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can vary widely but can include muscle spasms, numbness or weakness, and in some cases, issues that mimic seizures.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting with fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Infection
diagnoses.description: Viral infection damaging the immune system, leading to severe immunodeficiency and associated infections.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and possible night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: Bacterial or viral infection of the middle ear, common in children, causing ear pain and possible fever.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions including various forms of allergies and sensitivities, leading to a range of symptoms from mild to life-threatening.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin, bone marrow, and internal organs. It may present with skin lesions, gastrointestinal symptoms, and anaphylactoid reactions.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, affecting the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, leading to fatigue among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a pattern of hyperactivity-impulsivity or inattention that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease involves a gradual loss of kidney function. It can lead to electrolyte imbalances and affect various body systems.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears, leading to dry eyes and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to abnormal blood cell production, easy bruising, and electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Various conditions that impair liver function, potentially causing easy bruising, angioedema, and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema).

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins and minerals can lead to symptoms like easy bruising and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones, leading to electrolyte imbalances and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including the skin and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting the thyroid gland can cause a variety of symptoms, including irritability and dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: Hyperviscosity Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood becomes too thick, leading to problems like easy bruising and abnormal electrolyte levels.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 or 2 with complications

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Periodontal disease is common in people with diabetes due to high blood sugar weakening white blood cells, which are the body's main defense against bacterial infections that can occur in the mouth. Episodic weakness, increased appetite (polyphagia), and recurrent urinary tract infections may also be observed in poorly controlled diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of toxins and impurities in the blood, which can cause symptoms like weakness and changes in smell (dysosmia). It is also associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Periodontal disease is more common in chronic kidney disease patients.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
reasoning: Hyperthyroidism can cause increased appetite and weight loss despite the increase in food intake. It may also lead to episodic weakness. Although less directly related, individuals might experience changes in smell perception and are at higher risk for infections, including periodontal disease due to the body's altered immune response.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
reasoning: Multiple sclerosis can cause episodic weakness and changes in sensory perceptions, including dysosmia. While multiple sclerosis does not directly cause periodontal disease or urinary tract infections, individuals with MS may have a higher susceptibility to infections due to mobility issues or immune-modulating medications.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
reasoning: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by increased cortisol levels, which can lead to increased appetite. It also weakens the immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections, including periodontal disease and urinary tract infections. Weakness is a common symptom of Cushing's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
reasoning: While Addison's disease typically presents with weight loss and decreased appetite, it can cause episodic weakness and is associated with cravings for certain foods or salt due to electrolyte imbalances. Addison's disease may also alter the body's ability to fight infections, possibly worsening periodontal disease and urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
reasoning: A deficiency in vitamin B12 can lead to weakness and increase susceptibility to infections including periodontal disease due to a weakened immune system. Although less common, vitamin B12 deficiency can sometimes lead to an altered sense of smell (dysosmia).

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
reasoning: Iron deficiency anemia can cause episodic weakness and increased appetite in some cases. Individuals with this condition may also experience a heightened risk for infections such as periodontal disease and urinary tract infections due to an impaired immune response.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
reasoning: While hypothyroidism typically causes decreased appetite, it can lead to weakness and infections due to a slowed metabolism and decreased immune function, potentially exacerbating periodontal disease and urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
reasoning: Parkinson's disease can cause dysosmia as a symptom related to its effect on the nervous system. While it does not directly cause periodontal disease, urinary tract infections, or increased appetite, individuals with Parkinson's may experience these conditions due to associated autonomic dysfunction and swallowing difficulties, leading to poor oral hygiene and aspiration which can exacerbate UTIs.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: Chronic inflammation of the external auditory canal, often caused by persistent infection or skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome; a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the liver that lasts at least six months. It can be caused by viruses, drugs, alcohol use, or medical conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, weakness, diabetes, and liver problems. Hyperferritinemia is a common finding.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder characterized by severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway. It can be life-threatening if the airway becomes obstructed.

diagnoses.name: Acquired Angioedema
diagnoses.description: Similar to hereditary angioedema but not caused by genetic factors. It could be triggered by certain medications or other factors. It's characterized by sudden and severe swelling of the lower layers of the skin and tissues beneath.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can affect any organ. Symptoms depend on the organs affected but can include skin manifestations like bruising, kidney involvement, and nerve problems.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. SLE can cause a wide variety of blood abnormalities, including easy bruising.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy and excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high levels of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. It can affect various organs, including the skin, heart, and nervous system. Symptoms can include skin rashes, dysgeusia, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that occur when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs. Amyloidosis can affect the heart, kidneys, liver, spleen, nervous system, stomach, and intestines. Symptoms vary widely depending on the organs affected.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells. Symptoms can include easy bruising or bleeding, fatigue, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell, which helps fight infections by making antibodies that recognize and attack germs. Multiple myeloma causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells. Symptoms can include bone pain, weakness, fatigue, and high levels of calcium.

diagnoses: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (in rare cases with skin and gastrointestinal involvement)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation due to allergy
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Epilepsy (Postictal state can include vomiting and confusion, potentially mimicking syncope)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Angioedema (separate from urticaria as it involves swelling deeper in the skin)
Neurogenic Bladder (for incontinence tie into neurological causes)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents with symptoms similar to a stroke but lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like numbness, weakness, balance and coordination issues, and in some cases, visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord, often causing headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain can cause symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, balance problems, changes in personality or behavior, seizures, and numbness or weakness in parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of epilepsy may cause visual disturbances and sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where each headache is accompanied by temporary weakness, numbness, or paralysis on one side of the body prior to or during the headache. Visual disturbances and sensitivity to light and sound are common.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include weakness, difficulty speaking, and numbness or paralysis of the face, arm, or leg, often on one side.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden reduction in vision, pain with eye movement, and sometimes, symptoms like flashing lights (photopsias).

diagnoses.name: Conversion Disorder
diagnoses.description: A condition where patients present with neurological symptoms such as numbness, paralysis, or fits without a neurological explanation. It is thought to be a response to psychological conflict or stress.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms include paralysis, trouble speaking and understanding speech, and difficulty seeing in one or both eyes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms but without lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor occurs when abnormal cells form within the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A migraine that is preceded or accompanied by a sensory warning sign, such as flashes of light, blind spots, or tingling in the arm or leg. A migraine aura can include vision or speech disturbances and less commonly motor weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess is a localized infection or collection of pus. A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue. It can later spread to the joints, heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. The condition can lead to pain, and tingling or numbness in the extremities. It usually begins in the legs and feet.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), your body's main energy source. Hypoglycemia can cause various symptoms, including clumsiness, trouble talking, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system), leading to weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and other problems.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms may include weakness on one side of the body, dysarthria, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be benign or malignant. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, weakness, speech difficulties, and sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as weakness and numbness, which do not last long and fully resolve.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system—the network of nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can rapidly include weakness and tingling in the extremities.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms include headache, fever, and stiff neck, among others.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, seizures, and changes in behavior or speech.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to numbness, weakness, and pain, usually in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and time-dependent gothic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound. Dysarthria and aphasia can occur during a severe migraine aura.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can press on or damage nerves and brain tissue. Symptoms may include headaches, nausea, speech problems, and other neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', a TIA has the same symptoms as a stroke but they last only a few minutes and cause no permanent damage. It's often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain caused by a viral infection or other causes. It can produce headache, fever, confusion, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord. It leads to muscle control, strength, vision, balance, feeling, and thinking issues, and can cause speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, typically from a bacterial or fungal infection, leading to headaches, nausea, speech problems, and neurologic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is the inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can cause severe headaches, fever, nausea, confusion, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: This type of stroke occurs when a weakened blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the surrounding brain, leading to symptoms such as sudden headache, nausea, altered speech, and possibly unconsciousness.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal causing periods of unusual behavior, sensations including sometimes loss of awareness or speech disturbances such as aphasia and dysarthria during seizures.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (such as Encephalitis or Meningitis)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Viral infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Parvovirus B19)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with leukopenia, malar (or butterfly) rash, and proteinuria due to kidney involvement. Nasal ulcers can also occur in some patients.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily known for muscle weakness and skin rashes, dermatomyositis can sometimes present with features similar to those listed due to its autoimmune nature.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While more known for its effect on joints, rheumatoid arthritis can also manifest systemic symptoms, including leukopenia and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: This group of diseases can present with nasal ulcers and rashes due to inflammation of blood vessels. Kidney involvement can lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease characterized by dryness of the mouth and eyes, Sjögren's Syndrome can also cause systemic manifestations including rashes and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease features a mix of symptoms seen in systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, including potential for rashes, leukopenia, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, this infection can lead to leukopenia and rashes. While less common, it can also affect the kidneys and the nasal mucosa.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can present with leukopenia due to its impact on the immune system, various rashes, and kidney problems as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.rationale: Secondary syphilis can present with both cutaneous and mucosal rashes, including nasal ulceration. If untreated, it might cause a broad range of systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.rationale: Particularly in the chronic forms, leukemia can cause leukopenia. Skin manifestations and kidney involvement can occasionally occur, though they are less common symptoms.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Felty's Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA) with associated autoimmunity
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with associated autoimmunity
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis, requiring exclusion of organic causes)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (with secondary Sjögren's syndrome potentially explaining leukopenia)
Hematologic malignancies (e.g., Leukemia, Lymphoma - both can present with leukopenia due to bone marrow involvement)
HIV infection (can present with a range of symptoms including leukopenia and nonscarring alopecia)
Sarcoidosis (can have a wide array of presentations, including skin and joint involvement)
Psoriatic Arthritis (can have skin manifestations and arthritis; proteinuria might be secondary to medication or renal involvement)
Chronic Hepatitis B or C infection
Chronic Kidney Disease (secondary to glomerulonephritis related to autoimmune disorders)
Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)
Chronic Hepatitis B or C infection
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with systemic involvement
